notes:
1. Definition

The Maximum Normal Stress Theory (also known as Rankine's Theory) predicts failure when the maximum principal stress reaches the ultimate strength of the material. It is primarily used for brittle materials (like cast iron or glass) which typically fail by fracture rather than yielding.

2. Failure Criterion

Let $\sigma_1$ and $\sigma_3$ be the maximum and minimum principal stresses.

Failure is predicted if:

$$ \sigma_1 \ge S_{ut} \quad \text{or} \quad |\sigma_3| \ge |S_{uc}| $$
  • $S_{ut}$: Ultimate Tensile Strength
  • $S_{uc}$: Ultimate Compressive Strength

Brittle materials often have much higher compressive strength than tensile strength ($S_{uc} \gg S_{ut}$).

solvedExamples.question: A brittle material has an ultimate tensile strength of 100 MPa and an ultimate compressive strength of 300 MPa. If the principal stresses at a point are $\sigma_1 = 80$ MPa and $\sigma_3 = -200$ MPa, what is the factor of safety?
solvedExamples.explanation: We check both tension and compression. In tension: $n_t = S_{ut}/\sigma_1 = 100/80 = 1.25$. In compression: $n_c = |S_{uc}|/|\sigma_3| = 300/200 = 1.5$. The overall factor of safety is the minimum of these two values, so $n = 1.25$.
